content:
AUSTRALIA

Afterpay Touch (APT AT) - Co. group head Hancock intends to step down from board after conclusion of 2019 FY-end matters. (Newswires)

Coca Cola Amatil (CCL AT) - Co. is reportedly putting a bid together with KKR to buy spirits and wine portfolio from Pernod Ricard (RI FP). (Newswires)

GBST Holdings (GBT AT) - SS&C enters non-binding indicative proposal to acquire the Co. for AUD 3.25/Shr. (Newswires)

Gindalbie Metals (GBG AT) - Co. received request from shareholder Sandon Capital to consider potential liquidity options for its Coda Minerals shares. (Newswires)

Iluka Resources (ILU AT) - Co. is looking at entering the rare earth market. (Newswires)

NAB (NAB AT) - Co. is expected to begin securities business focused on Japan as soon as the fall. (Newswires)

Transurban (TCL AT) - Co. is said to be in discussions to acquire 15.4% stake in M5 West for possibly AUD 150mln- 200mln. (AFR)

Other News - Shopping centre landlords warned that another RBA rate cut might not send the right signal to consumers and could actually have a negative effect on spending. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

JXTG Holdings (5020 JT) - Co. signed agreement with Vietnam National Petroleum Group for building LNG receiving stations and joint procurement. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. is said to be in discussions with Didi Chuxing as the latter seeks to raise money for its autonomous driving unit. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Playstation unit head said they are considering M&A of game makers. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Heavy (009540 KS) - Co. has officially began the process to earn approval from anti-trust regulators for its proposed takeover of Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering (042660 KS). (Newswires)

Hyundai Merchant (011200 KS) - Co. will officially become a member of THE Alliance which is one of the world’s top 3 shipping alliances and will work with several companies effective April 2020. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. June car sales fell 8.3% Y/Y to 378.7k units, while it is reportedly to begin car production in Indonesia during 2021. (Newswires)

Kia Motors (000270 KS) - Co. June car sales fell 6.2% Y/Y to 236.2k units. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea Trade Minister says government will file complaint with WTO over Japan’s decision to tighten rules on exports of semiconductor and display materials to South Korea. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

PBoC Governor Yi Gang said the growth rate will continue to moderate as the Chinese economy gets larger and larger, while he added that the economy is close to potential. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Foreign Minister and PM Candidate Hunt said German Chancellor Merkel told him that she would look at a new package proposed by a new PM. (Newswires)

ECB's Knot said expectations for Q2 and Q3 are less favourable than for Q1, while he added that it is indisputable that inflation remains too low and the ECB is ready to act in adverse scenarios. (Newswires)

ECB's Lane said the central bank must pay attention to market-based inflation expectations and that anchoring of inflation expectations cannot be taken for granted. (Newswires)

Italy cut its 2019 budget deficit target to 2.04% (Prev. 2.4%), according to a government source. (Newswires) 

  • UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 48.0 vs. Exp. 49.2 (Prev. 49.4)
  • EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Jun) 47.6 vs. Exp. 47.8 (Prev. 47.8)
  • EU Unemployment Rate (May) 7.5% vs. Exp. 7.6% (Prev. 7.6%)

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC agreed to extend the oil output cut by 9 months at current quota levels, which means that the extension must now be approved by Non-OPEC partners including Russia at Tuesday’s meeting, while OPEC has also reappointed Secretary General Barkindo for 3 more years. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih believes compliance will be better in H2 and that oil demand is increasing but it is not necessarily looking firm for 2020. Al Falih added that he is confident Russia will fully comply with cuts and that large amounts of the supply overhang will draw down in H2, while he also stated that OPEC is now targeting the 2010-2014 inventory levels to assess the success of the deal rather than the five-year average and that they are raising security following the Gulf attacks. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh said OPEC members had constructive discussions and that he has no problem with oil cut extensions or deeper cuts, while he added that it is possible the new US sanctions have no impact on Iranian oil sales. (Newswires)

OPEC source said the closed OPEC meeting was long due to the discussion on the OPEC and Non-OPEC cooperation charter, where Iran was opposed to the rapid adoption of the charter and a decision should be made in the next meeting. (Twitter)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran's enriched uranium stockpile reportedly surpassed the 300kg limit, while earlier reports noted that Iran are to begin suspending additional nuclear commitments and are to surpass uranium stockpile limit from July 7th although the Iran Foreign Minister said Iran has not violated the JCPOA agreement in which he cited technical details. In related news, Israel PM Netanyahu said Israel will not allow Iran to develop nuclear weapons, while a senior Iranian parliamentarian stated that Israel would be destroyed within half an hour in the event that America attacks Iran. (Fars/Tasnim)

 

US

US President Trump thanked South Korea President Moon for hosting the American delegation immediately following the very successful G-20 in Japan, while he added that it was great to call on Chairman Kim of North Korea to have our very well covered meeting and suggested that good things can happen for all. (Twitter)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) warned of a chill over business investment from trade uncertainty and thinks they would have to discuss what to do with the policy rate if growth were to slow more, while he believes emotions have gotten far out in front of the data in terms of where we sit in the economy. (Newswires)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (Jun) 50.6 (Prev. 50.1). (Newswires)
  • US ISM Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 51.7 vs. Exp. 51.0 (Prev. 52.1)
  • US ISM Manufacturing Prices Paid (Jun) 47.9 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 53.2)
  • US Construction Spending (May) M/M -0.8% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Rev. 0.4%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Semiconductors soared on the open after Trump eased some of the restrictions on China’s Huawei. Gaming names such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) outperformed on strong Macau region casino revenue. Apple (AAPL) was an upward force on indices due to the G20 outcome being favourable for its China operations. Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) jumped after Brookfield Asset Management (BAM) agreed to buyout the railroad co. for USD 8.4bln. Boeing (BA) underperformed amid fresh subpoenas from the DoJ over its production of the 787 Dreamliner. Coty (COTY) nosedived after announcing restructuring plans that wold include a USD 3bln write down. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) gave a profit warning for its next earnings release, seeing the share price tumble. L3Harris Technologies (LHX), the L3 plus Harris merger, spent its first day of trade in the red. S&P 500 0.8% AT 2964, NASDAQ-100 1.3% AT 7768, DJIA 0.4% AT 26717.

Support for FI in early European trade came from a weak Eurozone PMI, which strengthened the Bund (and the T-Note in sympathy). But as the US got to their desks, the complex was sold, though there was brief buying after a mixed ISM report. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not changing by more than 1bps. US T-note (U9) futures settled 9 ticks lower at 127-22.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 1st July 2019: Traders fade G20 optimism, stocks close at fresh record highs
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 1st July 2019: Traders fade G20 optimism

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries down, dollar up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Favourable G20 outcome sees risk assets rally; OPEC+ to extend supply curb pact; mixed manufacturing ISM.

* COMING UP: Data: German Retail Sales, UK Construction PMI, Canadian Manufacturing PMI. Event: RBA Rate Decision, OPEC+ Meeting. Speakers: RBA’s Lowe, Fed’s Williams & Mester, BoE’s Carney. Auctions: Japanese JPY 2.1trl 2029, UK GBP 3bln 0.625% 2025.

* MARKETS: It appears as though traders have ‘sold the fact’ of both the G20, as well as the OPEC+ supply curb extension. Stocks gapped higher at the open, shortly printing fresh intraday record highs, though have been gradually grinding lower since. Similarly, the crude complex rallied early doors on the G20 outcome, and as OPEC and its partners reportedly agree to a nine month supply cut extension, though prices plateaued in the US pre-market, before falling to settle slightly higher, but well off-highs. The Treasury curve shape was largely unchanged, however, yields rose across the curve, slightly bear-flattening. The USD reigned supreme, which made it tough for other FX to make any headway, while havens saw outflows after one major market hurdle is now out of the way. Attention now moves on to the OPEC+ meeting on Tuesday, and jobs data at the end of the week, bookending the US Independence Day Holiday on Thursday.

* G20: Risk was on after the US and China on the weekend agreed to resume trade talks and suspend any further tariff hikes (existing tariff settings remain unchanged for now), as had been expected. However, a gulf remains between the two sides; Chinese press played down the prospects of a full trade deal, stressing that the 10% of the deal remaining to be negotiated still carried substantial differences (this includes issues around IP theft). Additionally, specifics of the meeting are still unclear, however, President Trump did state that US companies would be able to sell their equipment with no national security issues to Huawei. However, some have suggested that the lack of detail is still keeping some traders cautious, particularly since the relationship is still fragile, a deal is far from being reached, and as seen in the past, until the dotted line has been signed, the prospect of a breakdown in talks always remains.

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLED USD 0.62 HIGHER AT USD 59.09; BRENT (U9) SETTLED USD 0.32 HIGHER AT USD 65.06: Oil traded on the front-foot earlier in the session after Russia said it would support an extension of the supply curb agreement at current levels for 6- to 9-months at current levels (Iran seems to have an issue with when the agreement with OPEC+ comes into effect, reportedly), with the G20 outcome also supporting the demand-side of the equation, however prices reversed course heading into settlement, with a sell off in equity markets and a stronger dollar not providing any favours. The door is now open for OPEC to rubber stamp the agreement on Tuesday (monitoring committee favours a 9-month extension). While this emboldens the view of oil bulls, some desks have warned that the crude complex could be subject to some profit-taking, which seems to have been playing out in the US afternoon. Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih said he believes compliance will be better in H2, and that oil demand is increasing but it is not necessarily looking firm for 2020, but added that he sees a large amount of the supply overhang drawing down at the same time. Looking ahead to the API and EIA US energy inventory reports for the most recent week, current expectations see draws across the board, with crude -2.5mln bbls, distillates -1.2mln bbls, and gasoline -2.2mln bbls.

* US MANUFACTURING ISM: fell to 51.7 in June from 52.1 in May but did beat the expected 51.0, a decent headline, especially when taken in the context of weak Fed regional surveys in June. However, the other components were more ominous with the prices component falling into contraction at 47.9, significantly missing the expected 53.0. Construction spending also disappointed at -0.8% month-on-month. Although production and employment rose, new orders dropped to the lowest since December 2015, and sits on the neutral line. “We hope for a modest rebound over the next months, though, assuming progress is made on the China trade negotiations and the fitful recovery in China’s business cycle gathers a bit of momentum,” Pantheon Macroeconomics said, “in the meantime, manufacturing is soft, but it’s not soft enough to make a big difference to the overall pace of economic growth.”

* MANUFACTURING PMI SURVEYS: The official China manufacturing PMI remained at 49.4. Sub-indexes suggest weaker growth momentum in the manufacturing sector, though lower price inflation might have added downward bias, Goldman Sachs said. The Eurozone manufacturing PMI was revised lower, slightly missing consensus; new orders fell for the ninth straight month. UK manufacturing PMI sees back-to-back sub-50 readings for the UK manufacturing PMI since 2013, as the effect from continued Brexit-related stockpiling unwinds, while the fall in new orders does nothing to mitigate the headline.

* IRAN: Iran's enriched uranium stockpile has surpassed the 300kg limit, according to the IAEA, which puts the country in violation of the 2015 Nuclear Pact. This comes after the efforts made at the end of last week for the remaining signatories of the nuclear deal to reach an agreement, where although a new trade vehicle with the Europeans was established that could technically facilitate trade with Iran, whilst averting US sanctions, an Iranian official said that this was probably not enough for Iran to not break some of the pact’s components, as the EU would have to actually use the vehicle to trade (something that the US said would result in sanctions if used).

* RBA PREVIEW: RBA will announce its latest rate decision on Tuesday morning, where the central bank is expected to lower its Cash Rate Target for a second straight meeting; ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures signal a 70% probability of a 25bps rate cut to a fresh record low of 1.00%, although this has fallen from highs around 89% last week, while the implied yield curve suggests rates could decline even further to 0.75% as early as November. Click here for the full preview.

* FED: Now that the G20 risk has passed, desks will be looking to Fed speak to see how much scope remains for an emergency rate cut, potentially at the July meeting. How much of that we get ahead of this week’s payrolls report remains to be seen, with the Fed in data-dependant mode. There was nothing new in remarks from Fed Vice Chair Clarida; some desks had hoped he would be more decisive on where he stood on a 50bps July rate cut, after uber dove Bullard last week pushed back on the notion.

* ECB: Mersch on the weekend repeated his warning that downside risks to growth remain and toed the ECB’s line in pledging to keep rates steady through Summer of 2020. Rehn, who is in the frame for the ECB President role when Draghi steps down, said he’d be willing to tweak all tools as necessary. ECB's chief economist Lane said the central bank must pay attention to market-based inflation expectations, adding that the anchoring of inflation expectations cannot be taken for granted. ECB’s Knot acknowledged that expectations for Q2 and Q3 are less favourable than Q1, toeing the line that the bank is ready to act in adverse scenarios.

* BOJ TANKAN: Overnight, the large manufacturers Tankan index fell to 7 in Q2 from 12 in Q1 (consensus 9); the outlook component fell to 7 from 8.

* S&P 500 0.8% AT 2964, NASDAQ-100 1.3% AT 7768, DOW JONES 0.4% AT 26717. SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.9%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  0.5%, S&P 500 Energy  0.1%, S&P 500 Financials  1.1%, S&P 500 Health Care  0.6%, S&P 500 Industrials  0.2%, S&P 500 Information Technology  1.5%, S&P 500 Materials  0.7%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  0.8%, S&P 500 Utilities  -0.3%

* STOCKS: Semiconductors soared on the open after Trump eased some of the restrictions on China’s Huawei. Gaming names such as Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) outperformed on strong Macau region casino revenue. Apple (AAPL) was an upward force on indices due to the G20 outcome being favourable for its China operations. Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) jumped after Brookfield Asset Management (BAM) agreed to buyout the railroad co. for USD 8.4bln. Boeing (BA) underperformed amid fresh subpoenas from the DoJ over its production of the 787 Dreamliner. Coty (COTY) nosedived after announcing restructuring plans that wold include a USD 3bln write down. Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) gave a profit warning for its next earnings release, seeing the share price tumble. L3Harris Technologies (LHX), the L3 plus Harris merger, spent its first day of trade in the red.

* US T-NOTE (U9) FUTURES SETTLE 9 TICKS LOWER AT 127-22: Overnight, weak China PMIs did not see a move into Treasuries, with markets largely focussing on the favourable outcome of the G20 talks. However, support for FI in early European trade came from a weak Eurozone PMI, which strengthened the Bund (and the T-Note in sympathy). But as the US got to their desks, the complex was sold, though there was brief buying after a mixed ISM report. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not changing by more than 1bps.

* FX WRAP: USD was king, and the bid in havens unwound after the outcome of the G20, with JPY, CHF and XAU seeing outflows; JPY capped by 108.50, XAU sub-USD 1400. EUR saw downside, accordingly, falling below its 200dma (@ 1.1342) in early trade after Bund/Treasury rate differentials moved in favour of the buck, and EUR stayed sub-200dma after the weak PMI report. GBP was a function of USD strength for the most part, though the manufacturing PMI highlights the challenges the economy is facing, and additionally, the Speaker of the House Bercow has not selected the Grieve/Beckett amendment (that would have tried to curb the government’s spending powers in the event of a no-deal exit), which would have attempted to avoid a no-deal scenario. AUD is among the worst performers in G10 FX, and some desks have suggested that the weak China PMI has enhanced the prospects that the RBA will cut rates by 25bps at its meeting overnight, although others have said that back-to-back cuts may give the impression of panic; additionally, Governor Lowe pushed back on the efficacy of the rate channel at a time when many cbanks are in dovish mode. The TRY rallied as the US suggested it would not slap sanctions on Turkey after its purchase of the Russian S-400 missile system. After two decades of negotiations, EU and South American Mercosur nations (Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay) agreed to a trade deal at the end of last week, which will see tariffs between the two blocs substantially cut; BRL is higher, and traders will be looking to see a committee in the Lower House will vote on pension reform this week (keep an eye on the savings amount: the consensus appears to be around BRL 800bln of savings over a 10-year horizon). Meanwhile, the KRW (a great gauge of Asian risk sentiment) was lower against the USD overnight, not managing to garner much upside after the handshake between NK’s Kim and US President Trump.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar regains momentum after encouraging US PMI and ISM headlines
content:
USD

The Greenback has regained composure after a bout of early pm selling pushed the DXY down to fresh session lows of 96.275, and an upward revision to Markit’s final June manufacturing PMI prompted the revival. However, the index failed to extend recovery gains on a headline ISM beat as some sub-components were weak, especially prices paid and new orders (former tumbling below 50 and latter only just holding. Nevertheless, the Buck remains bid vs all major counterparts following the weekend G20 meeting and agreement between US and Chinese Presidents Trump and Xi to resume trade talks, and the DXY is holding just shy of a 96.650 high.

CHF

The clear G20 laggard and underperformer due to multiple bearish factors, including sub-forecast Swiss data (retail sales), survey news (manufacturing PMI deeper below 50), a general post-G20 upturn in risk sentiment and a degree of first day investor jitters as Swiss equities began trading without EU recognition. Usd/Chf is hovering closer to circa 0.9850 highs and Eur/Chf extended to 1.1160 before easing back a few pips.

AUD/NZD 

The Aussie is the next biggest major loser, and also in part due to weak manufacturing sector activity, but Chinese rather than Australian, as Aud/Usd slipped further below 0.7000 to sub-0.6980 and through 1.0450 vs the Kiwi that held up a bit better vs the Buck within a 0.6730-0.6685 range ahead of NZIER Q2 sentiment, capacity and building approvals later tonight. However, the big Antipodean event will be the RBA policy meeting overnight that is widely tipped to see another 25 bp ease on top of the ¼ point cut in June that will push the OCR to a fresh all time low of 1%, if confirmed – probability currently stands around 82% and a full preview has been posted on our Research Suite via the headline feed. 

GBP/JPY/EUR

The Pound lost ground in wake of a bleak UK manufacturing PMI, as the headline contracted faster than expected and output lost grip of the 50 handle to post its worst reading since the start of Q3 2012. Cable hit lows of 1.2633 from 1.2707 at one stage after declining through a pseudo triple bottom between 1.2665-63 and a Fib at 1.2646, while Eur/Gbp spiked towards 0.8980 from 0.8925 at the low. Elsewhere, a disappointing Japanese Tankan hardly helped the Yen, but in truth the mostly firmer tone between 108.10-53 trading parameters was due to safe-haven unwinding on the perceived positive G20 developments, while the single currency saw choppy trade on disappointing Eurozone PMIs and technicals within a 1.13374-12 band, and after some due attention paid to decent option expiries in the 1.1320-35 zone (1.6 bn). 

CAD/NOK/SEK 

The Loonie and Norwegian Krona both benefited from a bounce in crude prices to an extent, as Usd/Cad remained tethered around 1.3100 and Eur/Nok straddled 9.6800 vs Eur/Sek that failed to sustain post-Swedish manufacturing PMI momentum down to 10.5260 at one stage.

EM

In contrast to the Swedish Crown, Turkey’s Lira derived more support to compound a recovery of sorts in the manufacturing PMI from the absence of a specific reference to sanctions from US President Trump after his weekend get together with Erdogan, and Usd/Try fell through 5.6250 from 5.7910 in response. Similarly, the Real gleaned impetus from a better Brazilian manufacturing PMI to trade firmer vs the Dollar and Usd/Brl briefly dipped below 3.8100.

PREVIEW: RBA Rate Decision (July 2019)

  • Semiconductor names are up in pre-market trade after the Trump administration agreed to ease restrictions on China’s Huawei
  • Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) (Industrials/Road & Rail) is to be acquired by Brookfield Asset Management (BAM) (Financials/Capital Markets) and GIC for USD 8.4bln
  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had its estimates lowered at BofA. Elsewhere, Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives says Apple is the “clear winner” from the G20.

 

1st July 2019

  • Semiconductor names are up in pre-market trade after the Trump administration agreed to ease restrictions on China’s Huawei, making it easier for its US suppliers to trade with the company; RBC’s analysts think the news will benefit Synopsys (SNPS), Cadence (CDNS), Applied Materials (AMAT), ASML (ASML), Lam Research (LRCX), Micron (MU) and Western Digital (WDC), and may be negative for Nvidia (NVDA), AMD (AMD) and Analog devices (ADI) since their products represent potential security risks. Separately, Japan has implemented trade restrictions in the sector against South Korea over a long-held dispute of allegations of forced-labour during wartime, which could see demand diverted to other chipmakers.
  • Barron’s publication wrote positively on Carnival (CCL), saying it looks like a bargain; positive on Consolidated Edison (ED), Target (TGT), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), PepsiCo (PEP), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Illinois Tools Works (ITW), citing their index beating dividend yields. The publication also points out the outperformance of WPPCK - Walmart (WMT), Procter & Gamble, PepsiCo, Costco (COST) and Coca-Cola (KO) – compared to the FAANGs this year, and recommends investors hold on to the group.
  • The Macau region reported June casino revenue up by 5.9% YY to 23.81bln patacas. Gaming stocks in the region include Las Vegas Sands (LVS), MGM Resorts (MGM), Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Melco Resorts (MLCO).

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has had its estimates lowered at BofA, where analyst Wamsi Mohan says that despite the G20 outcome being a positive, third party data suggests a slowdown in China App store revenue. Elsewhere, Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives says Apple is the “clear winner” from the G20 as the major risk for the co. was the proposed new tariffs.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) the DoJ has filed a subpoena over its production of the 787 Dreamliner and complaints of unsatisfactory work, according to the Seattle Times.
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) announced in a filing that the change in liquids prices is expected to positively impact its Q2 upstream earnings by USD 0.4bln-0.6bln vs. Q1, however, the change in gas prices will negatively impact its Q2 upstream earnings by USD 0.4bln-0.6bln.
  • Pfizer’s (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) Phase 3 trial of its pulmonary hypertension in new-borns treatment, intravenous sildenafil with inhaled nitric oxide, failed to meet its endpoints for efficacy and safety, similar to the previous Revatio failure.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) is using VR to assist it in hiring new middle managers, which will assess how candidates respond to angry customers, messy aisles, and underperforming staff, the WSJ reported.

NASDAQ 100

  • Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) has denied violating US laws, following reports an AMD JV had given China accessibility to cutting edge processors, Business Insider reported.
  • Applied Materials (AMAT) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) is to acquire Kokusai Electric from KKR (KKR) for USD 2.2bln in cash, which after completion will continue to operate in Japan.
  • Biogen (BIIB) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced positive data from its spinal muscular atrophy treatment, Spinraza, Nurture study after 45.1 months of data.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is to ban ads on its platforms that encourage people in the US to not vote in the Presidential election.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – JMP Securities analyst Joseph Osha sees Model 3 deliveries strong in Q2 (exceeding 40k), and maintains his total deliveries at 97k (exp. 84k).
  • United Airlines (UAL) (Industrials/Airlines) – A United flight had to make an emergency landing at New Jersey’s Newark airport, after the crew discovered a braking issue on the Airbus (AIR FP, EADSY) A319 which also had two tires break on landing.

S&P 500

  • AbbVie (ABBV) (Health Care/Biotechnology), Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) – Barron’s publication wrote negatively on the pharma tie up, saying that AbbVie is paying a 45% premium for a co. with similar problems to its own.
  • Celanese (CE) (Materials/chemicals) has launched the shutdown of its Ocotlan, Mexico manufacturing facility, where it produces acetate flake, as part of its plans to consolidate its operations globally to strengthen its financials.
  • L3Harris Technologies (LHX) – L3 Technologies (LLL) and Harris (HRS) have completed their merger, naming Jay Malave as the CFO in addition to a USD 4bln share repurchase programme and a 10% dividend increase to USD 0.75/shr.
  • Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services), Amicus Therapeutics (FOLD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) – The two co.s have entered a strategic manufacturing collaboration.

OTHER

  • EQT (EQT) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) announced that independent advisory firm Glass Lewis has recommended its shareholders to vote in favour for the co.’s board nominees.
  • Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) (Industrials/Road & Rail) is to be acquired by Brookfield Asset Management (BAM) (Financials/Capital Markets) and GIC for USD 8.4bln in a cash deal at USD 112 per share, taking GWR private.
  • Performance Food Group (PFGC) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) is to acquire the privately held Reinhart Foodservice for USD 2bln in cash, WSJ reports.
  • PG&E (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) is lobbying regulators to allow it to securitise some of its profits to help it pay for wildfire liabilities.

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.9%] as the weekend’s positive US-China updates, among other geopolitical developments, generated risk-on sentiment which rolled over from the Asia-Pac session
  • US and China agreed to a temporary trade truce in which US will not levy new tariffs on China whilst also easing some Huawei restrictions
  • US President Trump met with North Korean Leader Kim in the DMZ and became the first sitting US President to enter North Korean territory
  • Russia & Saudi Arabia have agreed to extend the OPEC+ deal, and sources report that OPEC+ monitoring committee favor a nine-month extension on the output deal
  • Looking ahead, highlights include JMMC and OPEC meetings, US Manufacturing PMI (Final), ECB’s de Guindos, Lane, Knot, de Cos & RBNZ’s Bascand

 

WEEKEND HIGHLIGHTS

US agreed to not levy new tariffs on Chinese goods following the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20, while the sides agreed to restart trade talks. Furthermore, US President Trump stated the he had an excellent meeting with Xi which was as good as it was going to be and thinks US is “back on track" with China, while he also commented that the US will ease restrictions on Huawei as long as the transactions won't present a "great, national emergency problem". (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said talks should be held on equal footing, while China Global Times Editor tweeted that the “two sides agreed to restart trade consultations based on equality and mutual respect. This is important to Chinese side” (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump met North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Sunday and became the first sitting US President to step over to North Korea’s side of the border, while they agreed to resume stalled nuclear talks. President Trump later described the meeting as very good and very strong in which they agreed to work out details and added that “we’ll see what can happen”, while North Korea Leader Kim said it was good personal relations that made such a dramatic meeting possible at just one day's notice. (Newswires)

Russia and Saudi Arabia agreed to extend the OPEC+ output deal in which Russian President Putin said will be extended by 6 to 9 months at current levels, while there were separate comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak that the agreement to extend the oil cut deal is consolidated and other countries are backing an extension. (Newswires)

As a result, US equity futures gapped higher at the electronic open in which E-Mini S&P rose by around 1%, T-Notes fell lower by 12 ticks and gold declined 1.4% to below USD 1400/oz on safe haven outflows, while WTI rose over 2% on the risk appetite as well as reports Russia and Saudi agreed to extend the output cut deal.

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed following the US-China trade truce at the G20, while President Trump also met with North Korea leader Kim at the Demilitarized Zone and became the first sitting US President to step into North Korean territory. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by the trade sensitive sectors, as well as energy names after oil prices were buoyed by news of a Russia and Saudi agreement regarding the output cut deal. Advances in Nikkei 225 (+2.2%) were exacerbated by favourable currency moves and the KOSPI (U/C) was subdued by domestic tech weakness amid a dispute with Japan related to wartime forced labour in which the latter is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea. Elsewhere, the Shanghai Comp. (+2.2%) was buoyed by the US-China trade truce and after comments from President Trump which raised hopes of a potential U-turn on Huawei. This underpinned tech and telecom stocks with mainland Chinese markets the regional outperformers despite the miss in Chinese Manufacturing PMI data and absence of Hong Kong participants for holiday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they mirrored the slump seen in T-notes and heavy losses across safe-havens, while the BoJ also recently announced its bond buying intentions last week in which it reduced the amounts of JGBs with 3yr-5yr and 10yr-25yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8716 (Prev. 6.8747)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 49.4 vs. Exp. 49.5 (Prev. 49.4). (Newswires)

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 54.2 (Prev. 54.3)

Chinese Composite PMI (Jun) 53.0 (Prev. 53.3) Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 49.4 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 50.2)

PBoC adviser Ma Jun says there is a possibility of China growth to remain above 6% this year if US-China relationship doesn't worsen, when asked PBoC will following Fed monetary easing, says monetary policy mainly considers domestic economic situation. (Newswires)

- PBoC state that they will play an active role in responding to US-China trade frictions; will resolutely fend off systemic financial risks

Japan is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea amid dispute regarding South Korea’s ruling on wartime forced labour, while the South Korea Trade Ministry expressed regret over Japan's tighter curbs on tech material exports to South Korea and said it will firmly respond in accordance with local and international laws. (Newswires)

US

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) states that the US economy is currently in a good place with low unemployment, and inflation below objective level. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter) has warned of a chill over business investment from trade uncertainty, if growth were to slow more 'think we have to have a conversation about what do we do with the policy rate', and that he believes that emotions have gotten far out in front of the data in terms of where we sit in the economy. (WSJ)

GEOPOLITICS

Iran's enriched uranium stockpile has surpassed the 300kg limit., according to Fars News. (Newswires/Fars News)

- Prior to this it was reported that Iran are to begin suspending additional nuclear commitments and are to surpass uranium stockpile limit from July 7th, according to Tasnim.

Turkish President Erdogan said he has heard from US President Trump that there will be no sanctions regarding the S-400 missile defence system deal with Russia, although Trump did not explicitly say this at the press conference. Furthermore, a statement from the White House noted that “the President expressed concern” about the deal. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly asked US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to study factors which hurt Russia trade, according to IFX citing Kremlin spokesman. (Newswires)

Israeli warplanes fired missiles on Syria military positions in Homs and outskirts of Damascus from Lebanese airspace, according to reports citing a military source. (SANA)

UK/EU

UK Foreign Secretary and PM candidate Hunt announced a GBP 20bln no-deal Brexit war chest to support industries. Furthermore, Hunt said that the EU will not get “a penny more than is legally required of us”, referring to the EU divorce bill. (Telegraph/BBC)

UK Brexit negotiator Olly Robbins is reportedly to leave position shortly. (Newswires)

EU Leaders are reportedly close to agreeing on Timmermans as the next European Commission President, according to two diplomats, Giorgieva is to lead the European Council according to the diplomats; though they caveat that the deal regarding top jobs is yet to be finalised. (Newswires)

-- Prior to this it was reported that, EU leaders are still divided over who should get the EU’s top jobs. Centre-right leaders opposed a plan to give the post to Dutch politician Frans Timmermans, a candidate European Council President Tusk was reportedly proposing as part of a balanced package. (BBC/Guardian) 

ECB's Rehn states that the ECB is ready to adjust all of its instruments as is appropriate, and with symmetric approach inflation in the short run may vary around the 2% mark. (Newswires)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Jun) 47.6 vs. Exp. 47.8 (Prev. 47.8)

- German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 45.0 vs. Exp. 45.4 (Prev. 45.4)

- French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 51.9 vs. Exp. 52 (Prev. 52)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 48.0 vs. Exp. 49.2 (Prev. 49.4)

- IHS markit state that additional UK businesses are cutting back on both their day-to-day and capital spending

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are posting gains this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.9%] as the positive sentiment generated by the US and China temporary trade truce rolls over from the Asia-Pac session. Sectors are mixed, though predominantly in the green, outperformance is seen in Energy names which are also bolstered by the broader complex; in terms of the laggards, the defensive sectors, i.e. utility and consumer staples sectors are in negative territory. Towards the top of the Stoxx 600 are a number of semiconductors for example, STMicroelectronics (+5.5%), Dialog Semiconductor (+4.4%) and ASML (+3.3%) on the aforementioned US-China updates; however, also of note for chip names is that Japan are to restrict chip material exports to South Korea amidst a dispute concerning the countries ruling on wartime forced labour. Other notable movers include, ArcelorMittal (+3.0%) after the Co. has completed the sale of several steel-making assets to Liberty House Global for EUR 740mln. At the other end of the spectrum is Ericsson (-0.5%), who opened lower by around 1.5% as US President Trump commented that the US is to ease restriction on Huawei; as previously the likes of Huawei and Nokia have benefited from the Huawei restrictions. 

FX

CHF - The Franc has slumped across the board and only in part on a loss of safe-haven demand after the US-China trade truce forged on Saturday, as Swiss retail sales and manufacturing PMI both misses consensus by considerable margins, and the SMI kicks off H2 on its own after the EU severed links with the Swiss bourse. Usd/Chf is back up near 0.9850 and Eur/Chf has rebounded further above 1.1100 to just over 1.1150 vs recent lows of sub-1.1000 and circa 1.1055 respectively.

GBP - Sterling has also succumbed to all round selling in wake of the latest UK manufacturing PMI that was weaker than forecast and deeper in contraction territory, while output fell sharply from 50.3 to 47.2 and the worst level since October 2012. Cable recoiled from around 1.2707 at best through 1.2665-63 support that held several times in late June before breaching 1.2650 and a 1.2646 Fib on its way to a 1.2635 base, while Eur/Gbp has jumped towards 0.8970 from close to 0.8925 at one stage even though the single currency was pressured by disappointing Eurozone manufacturing PMIs as well.

JPY/AUD/EUR - The Yen has succumbed to the broad post-G20 recovery in risk sentiment, but not to the same extent as the Franc noted above, with 108.50 vs the Greenback tested and marginally topped before a relatively deep pull-back towards 108.25. A decent 1 bn option expiry may have capped the headline pair, while the DXY also faded after edging above 96.600 and a lack of follow-through buying to test near term resistance at 96.711 (June 21 peak). However, the Aussie remains on the backfoot just under 0.7000 ahead of Tuesday’s RBA policy meeting with a firm majority anticipating back-to-back 25 bp rate cuts, and the Euro is holding near the bottom of a hefty expiry zone from 1.1320 to 1.1335 (1.6 bn) having lost grip of the 200 DMA (a few pips below 1.1350) in the run up to the aforementioned poor PMIs and then breaching the 10 DMA (at 1.1328) to a 1.1315 low.

CAD/NZD/SEK/NOK - The Loonie and Kiwi are both down vs their US counterpart, but holding up better than most major rivals, bar the Scandi Crowns, with Usd/Cad only just above 1.3100 and Nzd/Usd hovering close to 0.6700. A firm rebound in oil prices is impacting, and also boosting the Nok (through 9.7000 vs the Eur), while the Kiwi is eyeing the impending NZIER Q2 survey for independent impetus. Note, Eur/Sek is back below 10.5500 in response to a rare manufacturing PMI beat from Sweden that will likely keep the Riksbank in hawkish mood on Wednesday.

EM - The Lira has extended gains made on the back of a relatively cordial meeting between Turkish President Erdogan and his US peer Trump on the G20 sidelines that assuaged concerns about sanctions over Russia’s imminent S-400 delivery with additional momentum coming in the form of a less contractionary manufacturing PMI. Usd/Try reversed from 5.7910 to 5.6735 in response before settling around 5.6950.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds crossed parity and matched their 172.91 contract high on follow-through buying in wake of softer than expected Eurozone manufacturing PMIs along with some technical buying perhaps as last Friday’s Eurex low at 172.46 was severely tested, but not breached. However, the 10 year debt future is still lagging Gilts that recently climbed to 130.70 vs 130.10 at the early Liffe base on the back of an even bleaker UK survey, while US Treasuries remain underwater and the curve is steeper, albeit well off overnight session lows and widest spreads ahead of US Markit PMI, ISM and construction spending.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+2.7%) and Brent (+2.7%) have started the week firmly on the front foot, with WTI having breached the USD 60/bbl level to the upside. Gains in the oil complex are stemming from a sentiment-driven gains (from constructive US-China G20 and North Korea outcomes) alongside an agreement between Russia and Saudi Arabia to extend the OPEC+ deal. The leaders discussed an extension of six to nine months at the level it is currently at (1.2mln BPD), with Russian Energy Minister Novak stating that the extension is a consolidated agreement and other countries are in favour of such an extension. Novak’s comments, and Russia agreeing to extend the OPEC+ deal, have removed a uncertainty from the discussion surrounding the deals future; as until these comments it was not known precisely what Russia’s position around an extension was and whether or not they would support one. In terms of scheduling for today we have both the JMMC and the OPEC meeting, with the closed session of the JMMC having commenced as of 10:00BST, and OPEC’s opening session is due to begin at 13:00BST, closed session at 14:00BST and a presser at 16:00BST, where we may get further insight into the OPEC+ extension; though an official decision will not be released until the presser following tomorrows OPEC+ meeting at 12:00BST. Note, the timing of the various sessions for JMMC, OPEC & OPEC+ is at best an indicative guide only.

Elsewhere, Gold (-1.3%) is suffering due to a firmer USD and a safe-haven unwind, as are other havens including JPY and CHF, with the yellow metal giving up the USD 1400/oz handle after this weekend's positive trade/geopolitical developments; having printed a session low of USD 1381/oz after the metals largest intraday fall for a year. In contrast, the trade truce has supported copper prices which are just shy of the 6-week high posted earlier in the session at USD 2.72/lb. Finally, iron ore prices have rallied in excess of 4.0%, supported by the overall risk sentiment and underpinned by supply woes.

Russian oil output 11.15mln BPD (June) vs. 11.11mln BPD (May)., according to two industry sources. (Newswires)

OPEC & non-OPEC Monitoring Committee members reportedly favor a nine-month extension to the oil output deal., according to a source. (Newswires)

To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

EQUITIES         

Major European bourses are posting gains this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.8%] as the positive sentiment generated by the US and China temporary trade truce rolls over from the Asia-Pac session. Sectors are mixed, though predominantly in the green, outperformance is seen in Energy names which are also bolstered by the broader complex; in terms of the laggards, the defensive sectors, i.e. utility and consumer staples sectors are in negative territory. Towards the top of the Stoxx 600 are a number of semiconductors for example, STMicroelectronics (+5.5%), Dialog Semiconductor (+4.4%) and ASML (+3.3%) on the aforementioned US-China updates; however, also of note for chip names is that Japan are to restrict chip material exports to South Korea amidst a dispute concerning the countries ruling on wartime forced labour. Other notable movers include, ArcelorMittal (+3.0%) after the Co. has completed the sale of several steel-making assets to Liberty House Global for EUR 740mln. At the other end of the spectrum is Ericsson (-0.5%), who opened lower by around 1.5% as US President Trump commented that the US is to ease restriction on Huawei; as previously the likes of Huawei and Nokia have benefited from the Huawei restrictions. 

FX

CHF - The Franc has slumped across the board and only in part on a loss of safe-haven demand after the US-China trade truce forged on Saturday, as Swiss retail sales and manufacturing PMI both misses consensus by considerable margins, and the SMI kicks off H2 on its own after the EU severed links with the Swiss bourse. Usd/Chf is back up near 0.9850 and Eur/Chf has rebounded further above 1.1100 to just over 1.1150 vs recent lows of sub-1.1000 and circa 1.1055 respectively.

GBP - Sterling has also succumbed to all round selling in wake of the latest UK manufacturing PMI that was weaker than forecast and deeper in contraction territory, while output fell sharply from 50.3 to 47.2 and the worst level since October 2012. Cable recoiled from around 1.2707 at best through 1.2665-63 support that held several times in late June before breaching 1.2650 and a 1.2646 Fib on its way to a 1.2635 base, while Eur/Gbp has jumped towards 0.8970 from close to 0.8925 at one stage even though the single currency was pressured by disappointing Eurozone manufacturing PMIs as well.

JPY/AUD/EUR - The Yen has succumbed to the broad post-G20 recovery in risk sentiment, but not to the same extent as the Franc noted above, with 108.50 vs the Greenback tested and marginally topped before a relatively deep pull-back towards 108.25. A decent 1 bn option expiry may have capped the headline pair, while the DXY also faded after edging above 96.600 and a lack of follow-through buying to test near term resistance at 96.711 (June 21 peak). However, the Aussie remains on the backfoot just under 0.7000 ahead of Tuesday’s RBA policy meeting with a firm majority anticipating back-to-back 25 bp rate cuts, and the Euro is holding near the bottom of a hefty expiry zone from 1.1320 to 1.1335 (1.6 bn) having lost grip of the 200 DMA (a few pips below 1.1350) in the run up to the aforementioned poor PMIs and then breaching the 10 DMA (at 1.1328) to a 1.1315 low.

CAD/NZD/SEK/NOK - The Loonie and Kiwi are both down vs their US counterpart, but holding up better than most major rivals, bar the Scandi Crowns, with Usd/Cad only just above 1.3100 and Nzd/Usd hovering close to 0.6700. A firm rebound in oil prices is impacting, and also boosting the Nok (through 9.7000 vs the Eur), while the Kiwi is eyeing the impending NZIER Q2 survey for independent impetus. Note, Eur/Sek is back below 10.5500 in response to a rare manufacturing PMI beat from Sweden that will likely keep the Riksbank in hawkish mood on Wednesday.

EM - The Lira has extended gains made on the back of a relatively cordial meeting between Turkish President Erdogan and his US peer Trump on the G20 sidelines that assuaged concerns about sanctions over Russia’s imminent S-400 delivery with additional momentum coming in the form of a less contractionary manufacturing PMI. Usd/Try reversed from 5.7910 to 5.6735 in response before settling around 5.6950.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds crossed parity and matched their 172.91 contract high on follow-through buying in wake of softer than expected Eurozone manufacturing PMIs along with some technical buying perhaps as last Friday’s Eurex low at 172.46 was severely tested, but not breached. However, the 10 year debt future is still lagging Gilts that recently climbed to 130.70 vs 130.10 at the early Liffe base on the back of an even bleaker UK survey, while US Treasuries remain underwater and the curve is steeper, albeit well off overnight session lows and widest spreads ahead of US Markit PMI, ISM and construction spending.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+2.7%) and Brent (+2.7%) have started the week firmly on the front foot, with WTI having breached the USD 60/bbl level to the upside. Gains in the oil complex are stemming from a sentiment-driven gains (from constructive US-China G20 and North Korea outcomes) alongside an agreement between Russia and Saudi Arabia to extend the OPEC+ deal. The leaders discussed an extension of six to nine months at the level it is currently at (1.2mln BPD), with Russian Energy Minister Novak stating that the extension is a consolidated agreement and other countries are in favour of such an extension. Novak’s comments, and Russia agreeing to extend the OPEC+ deal, have removed a uncertainty from the discussion surrounding the deals future; as until these comments it was not known precisely what Russia’s position around an extension was and whether or not they would support one. In terms of scheduling for today we have both the JMMC and the OPEC meeting, with the closed session of the JMMC having commenced as of 10:00BST, and OPEC’s opening session is due to begin at 13:00BST, closed session at 14:00BST and a presser at 16:00BST, where we may get further insight into the OPEC+ extension; though an official decision will not be released until the presser following tomorrows OPEC+ meeting at 12:00BST. Note, the timing of the various sessions for JMMC, OPEC & OPEC+ is at best an indicative guide only.

Elsewhere, Gold (-1.3%) is suffering due to a firmer USD and a safe-haven unwind, as are other havens including JPY and CHF, with the yellow metal giving up the USD 1400/oz handle after this weekend's positive trade/geopolitical developments; having printed a session low of USD 1381/oz after the metals largest intraday fall for a year. In contrast, the trade truce has supported copper prices which are just shy of the 6-week high posted earlier in the session at USD 2.72/lb. Finally, iron ore prices have rallied in excess of 4.0%, supported by the overall risk sentiment and underpinned by supply woes.

subject: ECB's Lane (Dovish) states that it is vital that a central bank demonstrates that it is always seeking the most effective methods by which to deliver on their mandate
content:
• Evidence indicates that the their enhanced forward guidance has been effective; it should be understood that a change to the data-based leg of guidance is not intended to ratify market views
  • The current policy mix includes four elements: (i) pushing the policy rate into negative territory, (ii) forward guidance on the future policy path, (iii) the APP, and (iv) TLTROs. Importantly, these measures work as a package, with significant complementarities across the different instruments.
  • Furthermore, the effectiveness of these tools also provides leeway for further easing if it is required.

1st July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed following the US-China trade truce at the G20, while President Trump also met with North Korea leader Kim at the Demilitarized Zone and became the first sitting US President to step into North Korean territory. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was lifted by the trade sensitive sectors, as well as energy names after oil prices were buoyed by news of a Russia and Saudi agreement regarding the output cut deal. Advances in Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) were exacerbated by favourable currency moves and the KOSPI (+0.1%) was subdued by domestic tech weakness amid a dispute with Japan related to wartime forced labour in which the latter is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea. Elsewhere, the Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) was buoyed by the US-China trade truce and after comments from President Trump which raised hopes of a potential U-turn on Huawei. This underpinned tech and telecom stocks with mainland Chinese markets the regional outperformers despite the miss in Chinese Manufacturing PMI data and absence of Hong Kong participants for holiday.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • US and China agreed to a temporary trade truce in which US will not levy new tariffs on China whilst also easing some Huawei restrictions
  • US President Trump had an impromptu meeting with North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un and agreed to resume stalled nuclear talks
  • Russia and Saudi Arabia have agreed to extend the OPEC+ output deal by 6 to 9 months
  • Asian equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed, gold fell below USD 1400/oz and WTI rose over 2%
  • Looking ahead, highlights include JMMC and OPEC meetings, EZ & US Manufacturing PMI (Final), German Unemployment Rate, UK Manufacturing PMI, ECB’s de Guindos, Lane, Knot, Rehn & de Cos, Fed’s Clarida, PBoC’s Gang & RBNZ’s Bascand

 

WEEKEND HIGHLIGHTS

US agreed to not levy new tariffs on Chinese goods following the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20, while the sides agreed to restart trade talks. Furthermore, US President Trump stated the he had an excellent meeting with Xi which was as good as it was going to be and thinks US is “back on track" with China, while he also commented that the US will ease restrictions on Huawei as long as the transactions won't present a "great, national emergency problem". (Newswires)

 

Chinese President Xi said talks should be held on equal footing, while China Global Times Editor tweeted that the “two sides agreed to restart trade consultations based on equality and mutual respect. This is important to Chinese side”

 

US President Trump met North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Sunday and became the first sitting US President to step over to North Korea’s side of the border, while they agreed to resume stalled nuclear talks. President Trump later described the meeting as very good and very strong in which they agreed to work out details and added that “we’ll see what can happen”, while North Korea Leader Kim said it was good personal relations that made such a dramatic meeting possible at just one day's notice. (Newswires)

Russia and Saudi Arabia agreed to extend the OPEC+ output deal in which Russian President Putin said will be extended by 6 to 9 months at current levels, while there were separate comments from Russian Energy Minister Novak that the agreement to extend the oil cut deal is consolidated and other countries are backing an extension. (Newswires)

As a result, US equity futures gapped higher at the electronic open in which E-Mini S&P rose by around 1%, T-Notes fell lower by 12 ticks and gold declined 1.4% to below USD 1400/oz on safe haven outflows, while WTI rose over 2% on the risk appetite as well as reports Russia and Saudi agreed to extend the output cut deal.

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed following the US-China trade truce at the G20, while President Trump also met with North Korea leader Kim at the Demilitarized Zone and became the first sitting US President to step into North Korean territory. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was lifted by the trade sensitive sectors, as well as energy names after oil prices were buoyed by news of a Russia and Saudi agreement regarding the output cut deal. Advances in Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) were exacerbated by favourable currency moves and the KOSPI (+0.1%) was subdued by domestic tech weakness amid a dispute with Japan related to wartime forced labour in which the latter is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea. Elsewhere, the Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) was buoyed by the US-China trade truce and after comments from President Trump which raised hopes of a potential U-turn on Huawei. This underpinned tech and telecom stocks with mainland Chinese markets the regional outperformers despite the miss in Chinese Manufacturing PMI data and absence of Hong Kong participants for holiday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they mirrored the slump seen in T-notes and heavy losses across safe-havens, while the BoJ also recently announced its bond buying intentions last week in which it reduced the amounts of JGBs with 3yr-5yr and 10yr-25yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8716 (Prev. 6.8747)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 49.4 vs. Exp. 49.5 (Prev. 49.4). (Newswires)

Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 54.2 (Prev. 54.3)

Chinese Composite PMI (Jun) 53.0 (Prev. 53.3) Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 49.4 vs. Exp. 50.1 (Prev. 50.2)

Japan is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea amid dispute regarding South Korea’s ruling on wartime forced labour, while the South Korea Trade Ministry expressed regret over Japan's tighter curbs on tech material exports to South Korea and said it will firmly respond in accordance with local and international laws. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Foreign Secretary and PM candidate Hunt announced a GBP 20bln no-deal Brexit war chest to support industries. Furthermore, Hunt said that the EU will not get “a penny more than is legally required of us”, referring to the EU divorce bill. (Telegraph/BBC)

UK Brexit negotiator Olly Robbins is reportedly to leave position shortly. (Newswires)

EU leaders are still divided over who should get the EU’s top jobs. Centre-right leaders opposed a plan to give the post to Dutch politician Frans Timmermans, a candidate European Council President Tusk was reportedly proposing as part of a balanced package. (BBC/Guardian) 

Fitch affirmed Sweden at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was slightly firmer and its major counterparts traded mixed with EUR/USD subdued as leaders remain divided over the bloc’s top positions, in which the pair fell through near-term support at 1.1350 where the 10DMA and 200DMA lingered in close proximity, and GBP/USD was stuck around 1.2700 throughout most of the session before a bout of Dollar strength took the pair below the figure. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was spurred by the US-China truce and reclaimed the 108.00 handle to the upside but has pulled back from intraday highs after running into resistance at 108.50, while antipodeans have failed to hold on to early gains with AUD/USD barely holding onto the 0.7000 handle after Chinese Official Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMI data both showed a contraction and amid wide expectations for another rate cut by the RBA in tomorrow’s meeting, meanwhile late Dollar strength took the pair below 0.7000.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with outperformance seen in oil prices after Russia and Saudi leaders agreed at the G20 to extend the output cut deal for up to 9-months which essentially makes today’s OPEC meetings a formality, although producers will still have to agree on the length of the extension and if there are any deeper cuts. WTI was boosted from the open and gained more than 2% to briefly test the USD 60/bbl level and recoup all losses late on Friday in which prices were pressured by news that a special EU channel to circumvent US sanctions on Iran was operational. Elsewhere, gold prices slumped below USD 1400/oz amid safe-haven outflows spurred by the US-China trade truce, while copper prices benefitted from the trade truce and gained more than 1% to a 6-week high.

Baker Hughes oil rigs +4 at 793, nat gas rigs -4 at 173, total rigs unchanged at 967; US drillers add oil rigs for the second week in a row. (Newswires)

EU Statement said Iran nuclear deal remains key element of global nuclear non-proliferation and that a special EU channel to allow trade with Iran and circumvent US sanctions is now operational. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Turkish President Erdogan said he has heard from US President Trump that there will be no sanctions regarding the S-400 missile defence system deal with Russia, although Trump did not explicitly say this at the press conference. Furthermore, a statement from the White House noted that “the President expressed concern” about the deal. (Newswires)

US President Trump reportedly asked US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to study factors which hurt Russia trade, according to IFX citing Kremlin spokesman. (Newswires)

Israeli warplanes fired missiles on Syria military positions in Homs and outskirts of Damascus from Lebanese airspace, according to reports citing a military source. (SANA)

 

US

Anticipation around the meeting between President Trump and Xi overnight has kept trading cautious on Friday, which was also the last trading day before month/quarter/H1 end. The Treasury curve was mixed, but yields only deviated by around +/- 1bps at settlement, with major curve spreads little changed. US T-note futures (U9) settled 1 tick higher at 127-31.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gained as US-China trade truce and US-North Korea meeting trumped over weak Chinese PMIs
content: Asia equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed following the US-China trade truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to not impose additional tariffs on China and with the sides to resume trade discussions, while President Trump also met with North Korea leader Kim at the Demilitarized Zone and became the first sitting US President to step into North Korean territory. ASX 200 (+0.5%) was lifted by the trade sensitive sectors, as well as energy names after oil prices were buoyed by news Russia and Saudi agreed to a 9-month extension of the output cut deal. Advances in Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) were exacerbated by favourable currency moves and the KOSPI (+0.1%) was subdued by domestic tech weakness amid a dispute with Japan related to wartime forced labour in which the latter is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea. Elsewhere, the Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) was buoyed by the US-China trade truce and after comments from President Trump which raised hopes of a potential U-turn on Huawei. This underpinned tech and telecom stocks with mainland Chinese markets the regional outperformers despite the miss in Chinese Manufacturing PMI data and absence of Hong Kong participants for holiday. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as they mirrored the slump seen in T-notes and heavy losses across safe-havens, while the BoJ also recently announced its bond buying intentions last week in which it reduced the amounts of JGBs with 3yr-5yr and 10yr-25yr maturities.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain as US-China trade truce and US-North Korea meeting trumps over weak Chinese PMIs
content:
Asia equity markets began H2 with gains across the board as global sentiment was buoyed following the US-China trade truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to not impose additional tariffs on China and with the sides to resume trade discussions, while President Trump also met with North Korea leader Kim at the Demilitarized Zone and became the first sitting US President to step into North Korean territory. ASX 200 (+0.5%) is lifted by the trade sensitive sectors, as well as energy names after oil prices were buoyed by news Russia and Saudi agreed to a 9-month extension of the output cut deal. Advances in Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) were exacerbated by favourable currency moves and the KOSPI (+0.1%) is also higher but with gains capped by tech weakness amid a dispute with Japan related to wartime force labour in which the latter is to restrict chip material exports to South Korea. Elsewhere, the Shanghai Comp. (+2.1%) is lifted due to the US-China trade truce and after President Trump commented that US companies can sell their equipment to Huawei, as long as the transactions won't present a great, national emergency problem. This has underpinned tech and telecom stocks with mainland China markets outperforming their regional peers despite the miss in Chinese Manufacturing PMI data and absence of Hong Kong participants for holiday.

In FX markets, the DXY is slightly firmer following the positive trade developments over the weekend and as its major counterparts trade mixed with EUR/USD subdued as it tests near-term support at 1.1350 where the 10DMA and 200DMA linger in close proximity, and with GBP/USD little changed as price action is stuck around the 1.2700 level. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was spurred by the US-China truce and reclaimed the 108.00 handle to the upside but has pulled back from intraday highs after running into resistance at 108.50, while antipodeans have failed to hold on to early gains with AUD/USD barely holding onto the 0.7000 handle after Chinese Official Manufacturing and Caixin Manufacturing PMI data both showed a contraction and amid wide expectations for another rate cut by the RBA in tomorrow’s meeting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they mirror the slump seen in T-notes and heavy losses across safe-havens, while the BoJ had announced its bond buying intentions last week in which it reduced its buying amounts of JGBs with 3yr-5yr and 10yr-25yr maturities.
